episodes.title: SUMMER SCHOOL 1: Choices & Dating

episodes.title: Planet Money Summer School
episodes.description: Introducing an economics education for your ears! We're calling it Planet Money Summer School. It's all the economics you meant to learn, but didn't get around to. Each Wednesday, we'll serve up a Planet Money story, or selection of excerpts, paired with insights from our economists-in-residence for the summer. Get an understanding of the basic concepts of economics going to the beach. You can pick up your economics knowledge while you bike, stroll the sand or just lay in the grass. Amuse your friends. Win arguments. Throw the words "diminishing marginal utility" into every discussion. Wednesdays in the PM feed this summer. (Fridays will be our usual coverage of the economy). Start listening to the episodes here.

episodes.title: Reparations For Police Brutality (UPDATE)

episodes.description:
Two highlights from our daily podcast, The Indicator, about houses. A plan to lower rents pits state against city, and a private firefighter breaks down his business for us.
| Subscribe to our weekly newsletter here.

episodes.title: So, Should We Recycle?

episodes.title: The Cost of Getting Your Money Back
episodes.description: Accidentally sending $1,500 to a stranger on Venmo reveals just how hard it is to get your money back in the new economy.

episodes.title: Tales From The Parking Lot
episodes.description: Three stories: A tire-booting vigilante, a surge price conspiracy, and the civil rights fight over parking tickets.

episodes.title: What Should We Be Worried About?
episodes.description: The economic recovery turns 10 this month. Don't get too comfortable. There's plenty to be worried about.

episodes.title: Are Cities Overrated?
episodes.description: Big cities used to be the land of opportunity for most people. But with changes in work, some economists are wondering: Are cities overrated?

episodes.title: The Planet Money Workout
episodes.description: Gyms don't want you to workout. Or at least, not often. It's better for business that way. Economics explains why.

episodes.title: The Day Of Two Noons
episodes.description: People didn't always know what time it was. But in the nineteenth century, a high school principal, a scientist, and a railroad bureaucrat synchronized the nation.

episodes.title: The Salmon Taboo
episodes.description: In Japan, salmon used to be garbage fish. Today, it's a delicacy. How one Norwegian with a lot of extra fish changed the tastes of a nation.

episodes.title: Quit Threat!
episodes.description: Sometimes an economy can get so strong the power dynamic between bosses and workers flips: Full employment. Are we there yet?

episodes.title: The Whistleblower Whisperer
episodes.description: Jordan Thomas is a lawyer who represents some of Wall Street's biggest whistleblowers. The life that led him here is extraordinary.

episodes.title: How To Meddle In An Election
episodes.description: In which someone runs a science experiment on an actual election, on actual voters, to test the persuasive power of ethically sketchy methods.

episodes.title: Trump and Deutsche, A Long Affair
episodes.description: After Donald Trump's companies declared four bankruptcies, several major banks stopped loaning him money. But Deutsche Bank didn't.

episodes.title: Counting The Homeless
episodes.description: From renting hotels to a jobs report-like census in the night, we look at ways communities are helping the homeless.

episodes.title: A Mathematician, The Last Supper, And The Birth Of Accounting
episodes.description: The story of an innovation that changed the way the world works, and of the man who made this innovation possible: Luca Pacioli.

episodes.title: How Uncle Jamie Broke Jeopardy
episodes.description: James Holzhauer took data, probability and a lot of practice with a fake buzzer, and turned it into a fortune on a game show.

episodes.title: You Asked The Listener Question Hotline
episodes.description: We answer a bunch of the questions you asked — and even one you *didn't* ask.

episodes.title: Economics, Sexism, Data
episodes.description: A young economist holds a mirror up to her field. And starts a national conversation about women in economics.

episodes.title: Why The Price of Coke Didn't Change For 70 years
episodes.description: For 70 years, the price of a bottle of Coca-Cola stayed a nickel. Why? The answer includes a half a million vending machines and a 7.5 cent coin.

episodes.title: Dollar Stores Vs Lettuce
episodes.description: Every six hours a new dollar store opens in the U.S. Are they killing grocery stores?

episodes.title: I Am Not A Robot
episodes.description: The remarkable story of the online "CAPTCHA" tests we've all taken to prove that we're not robots.

episodes.title: Two Spring Indicators
episodes.description: The Indicator from Planet Money explores trade wars, peanuts, hurricanes, and happiness.

episodes.title: How Much Does This Cow Weigh?
episodes.description: We wanted to understand an eerie phenomenon that drives everything from the stock market to the price of orange juice. So we asked you to guess the weight of a cow.

episodes.title: The Chicago Boys, Part II
episodes.description: How a ruthless dictator, and a bunch of economists known as the Chicago Boys, took Chile from socialism to capitalism.

episodes.title: The Chicago Boys, Part I
episodes.description: In the late 1950s and early '60s a handful of Chilean students went to study economics at the University of Chicago. What they learned changed their country.

episodes.title: Joke Theft
episodes.description: Copyrighting comedy is expensive. So comedians have devised an informal system of sanctions to protect their jokes from theft. Sometimes it works.

episodes.title: Tax Hero
episodes.description: Joe Bankman, professor at Stanford, figured out a way to make filing your taxes easy and painless. Then the tax lobby found out about it.

episodes.title: A New Way To Pay For College
episodes.description: Some colleges are offering students a new way to pay. It's not a scholarship. It's not a loan. It's more like the students are selling stock in themselves.

episodes.title: The Phoebus Cartel
episodes.description: The story behind two sneaky forces that drive us to buy more products, more often: Planned obsolescence and psychological obsolescence.

episodes.title: Bad Cops Are Expensive
episodes.description: There's an industry of people working to eliminate bad police behavior. They're not activists or protestors. They're insurers.

episodes.title: Why A Dead Shark Costs $12 Million
episodes.description: Today's show is about the fickle market for art. What makes a dead shark cost $12 million, and a photo of steel wool that looks like a tornado cost only $1,265?

episodes.title: The Stolen Company
episodes.description: When an American company named ABRO learns their goods are being counterfeited in China, they start their own trade war.

episodes.title: Cat Scam
episodes.description: The internet was supposed to get rid of middlemen--but instead they are taking over the global economy.

episodes.title: Mexico Fights The Fuel Pirates
episodes.description: Thieves are stealing billions of dollars worth of gasoline in Mexico. The President is taking drastic action to cut them off, and it comes at a serious cost. Content warning: Audio of deadly pipeline explosion.

episodes.title: The Starbury
episodes.description: The story of an NBA All-Star and an experiment: To make a desirable basketball shoe cheap enough for anyone.

episodes.title: Happy Fed Independence Day
episodes.description: The story of the day the Federal Reserve got its independence and the fight—an actual physical fight—to keep it.

episodes.title: New Orleans Vs. Airbnb
episodes.description: Airbnb has changed New Orleans. And now landlords and preservationists are fighting over the future of the city.

episodes.title: Antitrust 3: Big Tech
episodes.description: What does the rise of dominant tech companies say about competition and the state of antitrust law? Third in a series.

episodes.title: Antitrust 2: The Paradox
episodes.description: How Robert Bork won the fight over the very meaning of competition in America, and paved the way for some of the biggest companies we've ever seen.

episodes.title: Antitrust 1: Standard Oil
episodes.description: At the turn of the 20th century, Ida Tarbell investigated John D. Rockefeller's Standard Oil. What she discovered changed the economy of the United States.

episodes.title: A Fake Bank For Money Laundering Run By The Government
episodes.description: To catch drug traffickers, the U.S. government tried something it had never tried before. It set up and ran a fake offshore bank for money laundering. Fake name. Fake employees. Real drug money.

episodes.title: Our Valentines 2019
episodes.description: We give a shout out to the stuff we've been obsessing over in the office — those stories that were so good, we wished we had thought of them ourselves.

episodes.title: The Lost Plane
episodes.description: In December, a commercial flight had to make an emergency landing in Iran. They discovered that landing there would be easy. Getting out – much, much harder.

episodes.title: Who Won The Bet Over Bitcoin?
episodes.description: Five years ago, two sides met on our show to make a bet about the future of bitcoin. Today, we announce the winner.

episodes.title: Who Started The Wildfire?
episodes.description: After a wildfire, teams of investigators start combing the wreckage for clues. Finding the cause means, maybe, finding someone to pay. But where's the line between a natural disaster and a human one?

episodes.title: The Division Problem
episodes.description: Today on the show, we take on one of life's most vexing problems: Sharing.

episodes.title: Brilliant Vs. Boring
episodes.description: John Bogle died last week. His creation — the index fund — changed investing. Today, how his invention set off a million dollar bet between some of the biggest brains on Wall Street, including Warren Buffett.

episodes.title: The Pay-What-You-Want Experiment
episodes.description: In 2010, Panera launched several pay-what-you-want cafes. On today's show: How this charitable experiment worked out.

episodes.title: The First Shutdown
episodes.description: In 1879, Congress and the President were locked in a battle over the rights of African-Americans. It led to the first government shutdown.

episodes.title: You Asked For It, Yet Again
episodes.description: On today's show we answer questions about silver dollars, Venmo, and Brexit. Why? Because you asked!

episodes.title: All In
episodes.description: We go inside a professional poker tournament, where some of the smartest betting takes place behind the scenes.

episodes.title: The Price of a Hack
episodes.description: Hackers are an expensive headache for companies. But there might be a simple economic fix.

episodes.title: Do It For Your Country
episodes.description: People are the engine that fuels an economy. But what happens when you start running out of people?

episodes.title: The Rest Of The Story, Winter 2018
episodes.description: We check in on some stories we did this year to see what's changed. Find a full list of the episodes we referenced at our website, NPR.org/money.

episodes.title: The Curse Of The Black Lotus
episodes.description: How the card game "Magic: The Gathering" deflated a speculative bubble. You can support our show at donate.npr.org/planetmoney.

episodes.title: BONUS INDICATOR: The Calculator That Time Forgot
episodes.description: Most products in this world are vulnerable to creative destruction: as new products are developed, they make old ones obsolete. But there are some exceptions — products that persist, resisting change while economic evolution continues without them. For instance: the graphing calculator. (This episode is from our other podcast, The Indicator from Planet Money. Subscribe to it wherever you get your podcasts.)

episodes.title: A Very Planet Money Christmas Carol
episodes.description: Charles Dickens wanted to pick a fight with economists. So he invented Ebenezer Scrooge. But did he get it all right? Also: If you want to support our show, head over to donate.npr.org/planetmoney. We appreciate it.

episodes.title: Synthetic Reefer Madness
episodes.description: How a professor invented a formula for synthesizing cannabinoids and unintentionally helped launch a drug revolution.

episodes.title: BONUS INDICATOR: The Measure Of A Tragedy
episodes.description: Ricardo Hausmann, a Harvard-based Venezuelan economist, has constructed his own indicator, one that captures the horrifying scale of the economic catastrophe in Venezuela. (This episode is from our other podcast, The Indicator. Subscribe to it wherever you get your podcasts.)

episodes.title: The Prisoners of the Trade War
episodes.description: A truce in the U.S.-China trade war seemed close. The leaders of China and the United States were meeting to discuss a fix. And then arrests started. It got even more confusing, so today, we call up our man on the ground in Shanghai to make sense of it all. The key to understanding the latest turn in the trade war centers around a giant company most Americans haven't heard of called Huawei. Its rise traces the rise of China's economy and Chinese-style capitalism.

episodes.title: What's A Penny Worth?
episodes.description: We try to figure out what makes cents.

episodes.title: Is Amazon Good For New York?
episodes.description: It feels like all of New York City is arguing about Amazon's new office in Queens. But what do the people in Long Island City think?

episodes.title: Why Car Safety Is A Trade Barrier
episodes.description: The U.S. and Europe just can't agree on car safety standards. That puts car companies in a weird position, makes cars cost more and just seems kind of random and wasteful.

episodes.title: The Secret Target
episodes.description: Their plan was dangerous, risky, and extremely unpopular. But America copied them anyway. Today on the show: how a tiny country on the other side of the world changed how America runs its economy.

episodes.title: Kid Rock Vs. The Scalpers
episodes.description: We talk to Kid Rock about how he tried to cut scalpers out of the business — and still sell cheap tickets to his shows.

episodes.title: VIDEO: The Price Of Coke Stayed The Same For 70 Years — Why?
episodes.description: For 70 years, a Coca-Cola cost a nickel. The price didn't change. How is that even possible? You can also watch the video here: https://youtu.be/Bcz0BJGEVUY

episodes.title: Mugshots For Sale
episodes.description: We go deep inside the market for online mugshots. Is it extortion? Or is it a First Amendment right?

episodes.title: The Laws of The Office
episodes.description: You get what you measure. Work expands to fill the time allotted. Who comes up with this stuff? And is it true?

episodes.title: VIDEO: Put A Chip On It
episodes.description: A quick history of slow credit cards. This video also available here: https://youtu.be/2IksSNiEo2g

episodes.title: Kansas City Vs. Kansas City
episodes.description: A bunch of you asked why so many cities threw billions in tax breaks at Amazon. It reminded us of an episode we did in 2016.

episodes.title: Patent Deception
episodes.description: How World Patent Marketing stole nearly $26 million. And how the acting attorney general was involved.

episodes.title: VIDEO: A Grave Promise
episodes.description: If you die in America, chances are the cemetery is going to promise to maintain your grave forever. Americans take this for granted, but it's a wacky, wild promise that we maybe should not be making. You can also watch this video here: https://youtu.be/xYDYDThuJe4

episodes.title: Why Did The Cow Cross The Border?
episodes.description: To take advantage of the surprising benefits provided by an interlocked economic system on the other side.

episodes.title: Hot Dog Hail Mary
episodes.description: The Falcons are trying something radical: Making their food cheaper. It could break stadium economics.

episodes.title: VIDEO: Inventing Price Tags
episodes.description: For most of human history, you had to haggle over prices before you could buy something. Then came the idea of the price tag.

episodes.title: The Seattle Experiment
episodes.description: Seattle's radical solution to big money in politics: Flood elections with even more money.

episodes.title: The Halloween Tapes
episodes.description: Something spooky has been happening here at Planet Money.

episodes.title: Video: The Miracle Apple
episodes.description: We're kicking off a quick season of our bonus video series, Planet Money Shorts. Watch how apples became brands, and started being more than delicious.

episodes.title: Blacklisted In China
episodes.description: China is trying a bold experiment to help people trust each other more: The social credit score. Will it work? Does it go too far?

episodes.title: The First Lottery & How To Beat The Odds
episodes.description: The first lottery was a royal affair with poems, golden flatware and invited criminals. Also, how someone won the lottery over and over.

episodes.title: Trump vs. Red Tape
episodes.description: President Trump promised to slash regulations. How has he done?

episodes.title: What Causes What?
episodes.description: We try to tell the difference between correlation and causation.

episodes.title: The Student Loan Whistleblower
episodes.description: Seth Frotman worked overseeing student loans for the government. He saw things that made him quit, and tell all.

episodes.title: The History of Light (Nobel Edition)
episodes.description: Bill Nordhaus just won the economics Nobel. In this show: He shows how history of light is the history of economic growth — of things getting faster, cheaper, and more efficient.

episodes.title: Moneyland
episodes.description: We follow writer Oliver Bullough as he explores how stolen money moves around the world, and what that might mean for democracies.

episodes.title: Anatomy Of A Scam
episodes.description: Ever seen one of those signs asking if you want to work from home? We find out what happens when you call.

episodes.title: Special Report: Asylum Crackdown
episodes.description: We tell the story of a massive crackdown on asylum fraud, and the fallout.

episodes.title: Modern Monetary Theory
episodes.description: We rethink everything we know about government spending, taxes, the nature of money... All of it.

episodes.title: Tweak This
episodes.description: We propose small fixes for baseball, weddings, salary negotiations and buying your morning coffee. Warning: They may be too rational.

episodes.title: The Tale Of The Onion King
episodes.description: How one man took the onion market hostage.

episodes.title: The Central (Bankers') Question
episodes.description: We crash a party of central bankers to get an answer to one of the biggest economic questions of our time.

episodes.title: For Our 10th Anniversary, Episode #1
episodes.description: In honor of our 10th anniversary, we revisit our very first episode.

episodes.title: The 13th Hole
episodes.description: What a hole-in-one gone awry says about the state of charity.

episodes.title: When Subaru Came Out
episodes.description: Subaru's sales had been slumping for years. Then they went straight to their biggest fans: Lesbians.

episodes.title: Big Government Cheese
episodes.description: That time we accidentally created a cheese surplus so large it had to be stored in a ginormous cave.

episodes.title: New Jersey Bails Out
episodes.description: California just did away with cash bail. But credit where credit is due. New Jersey already tried something similar.

episodes.title: Food Scare Squad
episodes.description: When food makes people sick all around the country, an army of germ detectives jumps into action.

episodes.title: New Jersey Wine
episodes.description: Today on the show: Could New Jersey become the next Napa?

episodes.title: The World's Longest Yard Sale
episodes.description: Six states. Three days. One ugly cookie jar. Today on the show: Yard sale!

episodes.title: Trash!
episodes.description: The line between trash and recycling is moving a lot these days. It's a tough time to be a recycler.

episodes.title: You Asked For Even More
episodes.description: You have a lot of questions... about tariffs, unemployment rates, and RV dealerships, to name a few. We have answers.

episodes.title: Open Office
episodes.description: This episode is for everyone who ever had to ask their coworkers to quiet down. Today on the show: We meet the man who stole your office door.

episodes.title: Venezuela's Fugitive Money Traders
episodes.description: The Venezuelan government doesn't want you to know the real value of its currency. But Ruben and Mila figured it out. Now they're on the lam.

episodes.title: The Postal Illuminati
episodes.description: Is there a secretive postal organization fixing international shipping rates, and giving American businesses a bad deal?

episodes.title: Yes In My Backyard
episodes.description: There's a simple way to solve the housing crisis in U.S. cities. Only problem is, almost everybody hates it.

episodes.title: The Poop Cartel
episodes.description: What happens when a group of economists applies the number one rule of economics... to number two?

episodes.title: The New Socialists
episodes.description: Socialism was political poison in the U.S. for decades. Now it's gaining ground. Who are these new socialists? And what do they want?

episodes.title: The One-Page Plan To Fix Global Warming Revisited
episodes.description: Tax carbon emissions. That's basically the whole plan. What's the hold up?

episodes.title: Peak Sand
episodes.description: Sand. It's in buildings, windows, your cell phone. But there isn't enough in the world for everyone. And that's created a dangerous black market.

episodes.title: LeBron James Is Still Underpaid
episodes.description: The best player in basketball is getting hosed. The NBA team owners, the players, the fans and even LeBron James himself want to keep it that way.

episodes.title: Two Summer Indicators
episodes.description: Two stories from our Indicator team. There's a province in China that makes many of the world's flags. It's a unique window on global trade right now. And we find out why so few teenagers are working summer jobs these days.

episodes.title: Peanuts And Cracker Jack
episodes.description: It takes strategy and skill to sell snacks at a baseball game. Meet the hot dog vending legend of Fenway Park.

episodes.title: The Rest Of The Story Summer 2018
episodes.description: A pesticide wreaks havoc. A listener needs a bitcoin detective. And the search for the rarest economic good continues.

episodes.title: The Fake Review Hunter
episodes.description: Fake product reviews are wrecking the internet. But help is on the way: From a bodybuilding fake review hunter.

episodes.title: VIDEO: The Chicken Tax
episodes.description: Which came first, the frozen chicken or the tax on foreign trucks? Just kidding, it was the frozen chicken — then came the American tax that helped shape the domestic market for trucks.

episodes.title: When CEO Pay Exploded
episodes.description: Politicians have argued for decades that CEOs are overpaid. But there's this precise moment in the 1990s when CEO pay suddenly shot up. We find out what happened.

episodes.title: It Takes Two To Make A Trade War Fight
episodes.description: President Trump says China is stealing U.S. technology. So we looked into one case. And things got a little complicated.

episodes.title: The World's Biggest Battery
episodes.description: California has a ton of solar power. But as soon as night falls, it's gone. Today on the show: How to bottle the sun.

episodes.title: Inventing Accidents
episodes.description: The medical world has been trying to cure color blindness for centuries. Then a glass scientist figured it out. By accident.

episodes.title: Ungerrymandering Florida
episodes.description: When Florida outlawed partisan gerrymandering, politicians tried to sneak it back in...in disguise.

episodes.title: The T-Rex In My Backyard
episodes.description: Meet Sue, the dinosaur who sparked a gold rush for fossils buried in the badlands of North Dakota, Wyoming, and Montana.

episodes.title: REDMAP
episodes.description: Meet the man who figured out how to reshape national politics by making tiny investments in the smallest of places.

episodes.title: Nice Game
episodes.description: In game theory, sometimes the best way to win, is to lose.

episodes.title: Swamp Gravy
episodes.description: Today on the show: A small town stakes its future on writing, directing, and starring in a musical.

episodes.title: The Taxi King
episodes.description: Gene Freidman built a taxi empire. We visited him before he was in legal trouble.

episodes.title: Showdown at the WTO
episodes.description: The World Trade Organization: Can't live with it, hard to crush your trade opponents without it.

episodes.title: Class Action
episodes.description: Class actions run from big civil rights cases to arguments about pepper. Are they noble, or silly?

episodes.title: The Land Of Duty Free
episodes.description: We meet the man who invented duty free shopping and find out if these tax free stores are really saving us any money.

episodes.title: Fixing Chicken
episodes.description: Today on the show: A chicken index, some Wall Street investors, and an unlikely whistle-blower.

episodes.title: The Indicator Goes To California
episodes.description: California is way more than Hollywood. Today on the show, we look at what else is going on in this powerhouse state economy.

episodes.title: The Fondue Conspiracy
episodes.description: Today on the show: How a cheese cartel abandoned the rules of economics and convinced the world to eat fondue.

episodes.title: A Series of Mysterious Packages
episodes.description: Unordered trinkets have been arriving at homes around the country. We try to find out why.

episodes.title: The Bottom Of The Well
episodes.description: Today on the show: the economics of drought, and why the rational thing to do in California right now is use more water.

episodes.title: The Belt, The Road And The Money
episodes.description: Today on the show, we connect the dots between New York, Uganda, Prague, and China's thirst for resources. (Music Credit: Thanks to musician Giovanni Kiyingi for the use of his song "Kaleeba" from the album Amakondeere.)

episodes.title: The Rational Madness Of The Used Car Salesman
episodes.description: Why are used car commercials so annoying? Meet the original sinner.

episodes.title: Tariffied
episodes.description: We're in a full-fledged trade war with China. We dig into the list of tariffs on American products. It gets weird...and delicious.

episodes.title: The Less Deadly Catch
episodes.description: Today on the show: how an economic fix helped made the deadliest job in America safer, and why people are angry about it.

episodes.title: NDA Tell-All
episodes.description: Today on the show, we talk to one of the most famous NDA breakers of all time, and ask: Is there a legal way out of your NDA?

episodes.title: Larry vs. The IRS
episodes.description: What exactly would happen if you didn't pay your taxes? Today on the show, we follow one man who did just that.

episodes.title: Worst. Tariffs. Ever.
episodes.description: Tariffs are stupid. This is one of the few things economists can agree on. Today, we bring you the story of the worst tariffs ever.

episodes.title: Mulvaney Vs The CFPB
episodes.description: What happens when you put someone who wants to close an agency, in charge of that agency? Today on the show, we find out.

episodes.title: An Insider Trader Tells All
episodes.description: A man who got caught insider trading explains everything — what he did, how he did it, and why.

episodes.title: The Golden Rules
episodes.description: Planet Money joins the gold rush 170 years late. And the rules are still about the same. How did that happen?

episodes.title: The Lollipop War
episodes.description: What do sugar farmers have against candy? A lot, according to candy manufacturers.

episodes.title: XXX-XX-XXXX
episodes.description: How did the social security number become the most important identifier in the United States? And is that even a good idea?

episodes.title: Rigging The Economy
episodes.description: Two guys from different ends of the political spectrum agree that the economy is rigged. And they think they know who's responsible.

episodes.title: The Experiment Experiment
episodes.description: There's something wrong with the way we're doing science. Today on the show, we find out how to fix it.

episodes.title: You Asked For More
episodes.description: We ponder the price of chicken, safe haven currencies, and the cash value of coupons. Why? Because you asked.

episodes.title: Three Indicators
episodes.description: What do human blood, the conservative tax plan, and beer hops tell us about the world? Find out in today's episode.

episodes.title: The Vodka Proof
episodes.description: Vodka is the best selling spirit in the United States, and there are zillions of brands. But is there any difference between them?

episodes.title: The Blue Pallet
episodes.description: How do you reinvent something as simple as the wooden shipping pallet?

episodes.title: Who Started The Wildfire
episodes.description: After a wildfire, teams of investigators start combing the wreckage for clues. Finding the cause means, maybe, finding someone to pay. But where's the line between a natural disaster and a human one?

episodes.title: Our Valentines
episodes.description: If you can't beat 'em, send 'em a valentine.

episodes.title: Planet Monet
episodes.description: Investors are pouring money into art, and a lot of it is disappearing into storage. We try to find out where the art goes, and why it goes there.

episodes.title: The Secret Document that Transformed China
episodes.description: In 1978, a group of farmers in a Chinese village wrote a contract and hid it in the roof of a hut. They were afraid the document might get them executed. Instead, it transformed the Chinese economy.

episodes.title: The Shortest Super Bowl
episodes.description: How does the market for Super Bowl tickets work? And why did it collapse in 2015?

episodes.title: The Other Davos
episodes.description: Billionaires, diplomats, thinkfluencers. This is the Davos everyone hears about. Today on the show, we take you to a different Davos.

episodes.title: P Is For Phosphorus
episodes.description: Phosphate is a crucial element, for farming, and for life. And there aren't too many places to get it. What if it runs out?

episodes.title: Tax Me If You Can
episodes.description: Douglas Bruce had a bold vision for Colorado.

episodes.title: A Bet On The Future Of Humanity
episodes.description: A biologist predicts a population bomb that will lead to global catastrophe. An economist sees a limitless future for mankind. The result is one of the most famous bets in economics.

episodes.title: The Problem Of The Root
episodes.description: The wild ginseng market has gone crazy. We go to a farm hidden in the Appalachian mountains to find out why.

episodes.title: The Gun Man
episodes.description: Will 3-D printing make gun control impossible?

episodes.title: The Invisible Plumbing Of Our Economy
episodes.description: Why does it take days to send money electronically?

episodes.title: Bitcoin Losers
episodes.description: The Bitcoin market has gone crazy. And it's revealing something strange. A lot of people can't find their Bitcoins. We go looking for lost billions.

episodes.title: When The U.S. Paid Off The Entire National Debt
episodes.description: What does a country with no debt look like? To find out, we went back to the United States in 1835.

episodes.title: The Rest of the Story 2017
episodes.description: Every year at Planet Money, we take a cue from radio legend Paul Harvey and bring you "The Rest of the Story." It's a show where we check in on some of the episodes that we've done in the past year, and tell you what's changed.

episodes.title: The M&M Anomaly
episodes.description: David Kestenbaum noticed that a pack of Milk Chocolate M&M's weighs 1.69 ounces, but a pack of Peanut Butter M&M's weighs 1.63 ounces. He had to know why. But the confectionary world has its secrets.

episodes.title: BONUS INDICATOR: How Airfare Is Changing
episodes.description: Why flying to small airports keeps costing more and more, just as flying to big airports is getting cheaper. (This episode is from our new podcast, The Indicator. Subscribe to it wherever you get your podcasts.)

episodes.title: The Tax Plan Is Huge
episodes.description: Congress just passed the largest tax overhaul in decades. We dig in.

episodes.title: The Santa Suit
episodes.description: Today on the show: A lawsuit over a Santa suit is a window into countless hidden fights that shape the stuff we buy. It's one man's battle against the U.S. government — and, in a way, against himself.

episodes.title: BONUS INDICATOR: Forget Neutrality
episodes.description: From our new podcast, The Indicator: Opponents of net neutrality argue that the government should get out of the way and let the market work, that's what leads to better service and more choice. We examine that logic.

episodes.title: SPACE 4: 3 2 1
episodes.description: Five reporters go to the New York Produce Show and Conference, each on a mission.

episodes.title: High Rise, Low Returns
episodes.description: As a businessman, President Trump is known for his towering buildings. Today we tell the story of one of those skyscrapers and what it says about how and with whom Trump does business.

episodes.title: BONUS: The Indicator, From Planet Money
episodes.description: We've made a new show. You can subscribe to it now. It's called 'The Indicator'. It's for those times you want Planet Money to explain the news, quickly. It's short (about five minutes) and three days a week.

episodes.title: SPACE 4: 3 2 1
episodes.description: We've got a satellite. We got a rocket. We're heading to the launch pad.

episodes.title: SPACE 3: Rocket Shopping
episodes.description: We found a satellite. We tried to figure out what it would do. Now we need to choose our rocket.

episodes.title: SPACE 2: Wait, Why Are We Going To Space?
episodes.description: We hitched a ride on a satellite. Now we have to figure out what we're going to do up there.

episodes.title: SPACE 1: We're Going To Space
episodes.description: We really are going to space.

episodes.title: Anatomy of a Hustle
episodes.description: What did Paul Manafort do, exactly? Robert Mueller's indictment is 31 pages of hard-to-understand financial crime. We try to figure it out.

episodes.title: The Free Food Market
episodes.description: A while back, the charity Feeding America was a mess. It was sending pickles to food banks that wanted produce, and potatoes to Idaho. So they called some economists, and a free food market was born.

episodes.title: Walmart's Pickle
episodes.description: Walmart and Amazon are in a battle to be the store where you buy everything. But when both companies sell everything, what sets them apart? Food inventions like a bright, red pickle!

episodes.title: War And Peace And Cows
episodes.description: In South Sudan, there is a kind of money that works even through bank failures and unstable governments. But when war struck, it upended a whole economy: the economy of cows.

episodes.title: Bagging the Birkin
episodes.description: Once you've got a Birkin bag, you've made it. But to get one, you need more than just money. Birkins always seem to be mysteriously out of stock. This is no accident.

episodes.title: Your Cell Phone's A Snitch
episodes.description: Timothy Carpenter stole cell phones. Then his phone sold him out to the Feds. Now the Supreme Court has to decide how private our cell phone data should be.

episodes.title: If Teens Ran the Fed
episodes.description: Once a year, teenagers from across the country team up and compete to run the U.S. Federal Reserve.

episodes.title: Nudge, Nudge, Nobel
episodes.description: Why do smart people make dumb decisions? Figuring that out won Richard Thaler a Nobel Prize.

episodes.title: The Hotel at the Center of the World
episodes.description: A Chinese company pays millions of dollars for a failing hotel in a small, rural town. We follow the trail of money, and it explains the world economy.

episodes.title: Is the NCAA An Illegal Cartel?
episodes.description: In any other industry, it's illegal for a group of companies to get together and cap wages. What makes the NCAA different?

episodes.title: The Death Show
episodes.description: Today on the show: death. We have four stories about how people prepare for death and what they leave behind for the living.

episodes.title: Free Money
episodes.description: Bob Peterson claims to have found the thing people have sought for thousands of years — an investment guaranteed to double in value. He keeps it in a storage locker in Utah. It's protected by a single padlock.

episodes.title: North Korea's Capitalists
episodes.description: Capitalism isn't supposed to exist in North Korea. But all over the country, small businesses are popping up, growing the nation's economy. And much of that money is going straight to the country's nuclear program.

episodes.title: Corporate! Income! Tax!
episodes.description: Republicans are proposing big changes to the corporate income tax. Trillions of dollars are at stake. Here's what it all means.

episodes.title: Bad Credit Bureau
episodes.description: For most of our lives, Equifax has been slurping up our financial data. Now the company's been hacked and our data is loose. Today, we trace this mess back to two brothers and one fateful decision.

episodes.title: The Benefits of Bankruptcy
episodes.description: It might just be the secret weapon of the U.S. economy.

episodes.title: Flood Money
episodes.description: Bill Pennington's house floods a lot: Three times in the last three years. And every time his house floods, the government pays to help him repair the damage. Is something wrong here?

episodes.title: Mr Jones' Act
episodes.description: The government suspended the Jones Act last week, to allow non-US ships to move fuel to victims of hurricanes in Houston and Florida. Which once again made us wonder why the act even exists.

episodes.title: The Basic Income Experiment
episodes.description: The basic income. A flat payment to citizens, without strings. Is it a progressive fever dream, or sensible policy? We may soon find out. The Finnish Government is testing it on 2,000 citizens.

episodes.title: Is Record Breaking Broken?
episodes.description: The Guinness Book of World Records had a problem. It was a book. And books aren't selling as well as they used to. So Guinness changed what they were selling, and who they were selling to.

episodes.title: How To Make It In The Music Business
episodes.description: Behind almost all popular music, there is this hidden economy of music producers buying and selling sonic snippets, texting each other half-finished beats, and angling for back-end royalties.

episodes.title: Hard Work Is Irrelevant
episodes.description: Patty McCord helped create a workplace at Netflix that runs more like a professional sports team than a family. If you're not up to scratch, you're off the team. Is this the future of work?

episodes.title: This Week in Time Bombs
episodes.description: We look at three time bombs Congress is sitting on: The federal budget, the debt ceiling, and DREAMers.

episodes.title: This Ad's For You
episodes.description: Tom Burrell was the first black man in Chicago advertising. He went on to change the way we think about ads, and the way advertisers think about us.

episodes.title: The Ransom Problem
episodes.description: When someone has been kidnapped, what do you do? If you pay ransom, you create a market for hostages. If you don't, people die. Different countries have different policies with different results.

episodes.title: Tips From Spies
episodes.description: There's an entire universe of things spies are not allowed to tell us. Today on the show, a few of the teeny things they can say. They might come in handy.

episodes.title: Rough Translation in Ukraine
episodes.description: Fake news from Russia helped spark a real war in Ukraine. What can Ukraine's fight against fake news teach the US?

episodes.title: The Hydrox Resurrection
episodes.description: Hidden in the trash heap of commerce there is buried treasure. Abandoned brands--including trusted, beloved brands--are waiting to be claimed and reborn. Today on the show: A cookie comeback.

episodes.title: Robocall Invasion
episodes.description: Your phone rings--it looks like your neighbor's calling. But instead, it's the creepiest scam of the year.

episodes.title: The Anti-Store
episodes.description: Costco made shopping harder, and customers loved it. Now a new company is taking the Costco experience to new extremes.

episodes.title: Robert And Kenny Go To The Fair
episodes.description: When we go to the state fair, we don't go for the rides, deep-fried tacos or the butter cow. We head straight for the vendor marketplace to meet the masters of the lost art of salesmanship.

episodes.title: Can You Patent a Steak?
episodes.description: We visit the workshop of the meat inventor who came up with Steak-Umm and KFC's popcorn chicken. And we try to figure out what meat inventors tell us about patents and innovation.

episodes.title: Google Is Big. Is That Bad?
episodes.description: Google just got hit with a multibillion-dollar antitrust fine. Here's what it tells us about competition, market power, and the biggest corporations on the planet.

episodes.title: The Eddie Murphy Rule
episodes.description: We answer one of the most important questions in finance: What actually happens at the end of Trading Places?

episodes.title: Rest of the Story 2017, Vol. 1
episodes.description: News moves fast. Some of our best stories from this year have new chapters. Here, we catch up on three: Dirty trademarks, trading bots, and the war against the bald eagle.

episodes.title: Buy Low, Sell Prime
episodes.description: Sam Cohen buys stuff at big retail stores, then turns around and sells it on Amazon for a quick profit. It defies economic logic. But somehow, there's a whole multimillion-dollar industry doing this.

episodes.title: The Starbury
episodes.description: Most athlete endorsements make a product more expensive. But what happens when an NBA All-Star uses his name to make a sneaker much, much cheaper? On today's show: How that worked out.

episodes.title: Board Games
episodes.description: On today's show: The story of two guys who tried to cut the pay of a CEO at a small pneumatic tool company.

episodes.title: Meeting The Russians
episodes.description: That meeting between Donald Trump Jr. and a Russian lawyer was two decades in the making. It began in 1996, when an adventurous American went to Russia, trying to make a buck.

episodes.title: New Jersey Bails Out
episodes.description: Bail is broken. In New Jersey, defense attorneys, prosecutors, and judges banded together to try a dramatic solution: Blow it up.
